title: The name lfortran vs ifortran
body:
*Original issue*: https://gitlab.com/lfortran/lfortran/-/issues/356

Hello,

Naming is important; is LFortran really the right name?  
https://twitter.com/OndrejCertik/status/1367547776133787649

  > But why isnâ€™t it iFortran? *duck* ;)

  > That is a very good question:  
    originally I wanted to call it ifortran (and ifort in short),  
    but the problem is that ifort is already the name of the  
    executable for the Intel Fortran compiler,  
    one of the most mature Fortran compilers.  
    It would bee too much of a confusion.  

ifortran seems the right, obvious name for "Interactive Fortran".  
The name seems up for grabs (a quick search doesn't find any hits).  
There's no need to shorten it to ifort - that would be confusing.

If L is for LLVM then it shackles LFortran to LLVM -  
then what would a Gnu backend for LFortran be called?

As a first time browser I might not have looked at LFortran at all,  
because - "What the L"?

I like ipython, I like notebooks, I liked Matlab, I'd like ifortran  
please.
